hi everyone Anthony Fantana here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review battles is a New York
quartet recently turned trio and this is
their sophomore LP gloss drop and the
loss of tie and a Braxton as a frontman
a multi-instrumentalist in this group
bred a lot of rumors about this album
what is it going to sound like why our
battles continuing to call themselves
battles after losing such a pivotal
member and of course the first single to
come off of this LP ice cream featuring
Matias Aguayo on vocals featured on that
track only fueled flames only fueled
rumors and guessing games considering a
lineup change a series of guest
vocalists on this album and the fact
that this is a sophomore LP coming on
the coattails of a very beloved first
album the cards were kind of stacked
against this LP battles was challenged
on this record and I'm happy to say in
my opinion they met that challenge for
me battles have maintained those
intricate and complex and experimental
elements that made their first LP so
appealing but they've also taken gloss
drop and used it as an opportunity to
almost put a friendlier and more
accessible face on their music but in
doing that they haven't dumbed it down
this thing is a really hyper very active
album it is a high-octane non stopped
experimental dance rock party that just
makes me want to move move move move
move move move move move move move move
I just want to jump around and eat candy
to this album I want to try eating the
pink stuff that's on the cover I want to
jump around in a clown shape bouncy
castle that's as big as a house it's
weird to be in my mid-20s and feel that
way but this album put me there and I'm
thankful for that it's just got this
rebellious ly youthful feel to it and
yet it's so seasoned and experienced and
complex there are certain subjects I
like to harp on in my reviews a lot like
interplay and a live feel to a band to
me that kind of stuff makes a record
exciting and this album has so much of
that hearing these guys bounce off of
each other on these tracks is a serious
tree for me because they really know how
to work a rhythm each track on here
moves differently in the guitars the
synthesizers of the drums are always
figuring out different ways to dance
around the tempo and interact with one
another
I mean John stanner puts so much heart
into the way he plays drums on this LP
and just in general as good as the
guitars and the synthesizers are on this
album the drums are really the driving
force for me I love this guy's fills how
subtly he builds up to certain parts in
the songs and his improvisations too but
the thing is everybody is improvising on
this album there's so many tracks here
that don't really feel like they've been
written out or realized beforehand like
the band is making them up as they go
along Futura inchworm wall street these
songs have a certain climax or a post
that the band is eventually going to hit
usually like a keyboard melody kind of
flies in there's a breakdown and a
thematic melody plays but when the band
actually gets there doesn't really seem
to be decided because these songs kind
of progress forward as the band
sees fit with every little added extra
drum hit or book on the guitar or
synthesizer note the song just moves an
inch closer to its final destination but
there are some tracks on here where
battles are a little bit clearer and
confined themselves to a structure maybe
a pop structure or something like that
an ice-cream is definitely one of those
tracks which after hearing that song
multiple multiple multiple times I'm
pretty sure it's it's the most fun song
of 2011 the the way it opens the ooh ah
ish whoosh and the building circus organ
synthesizers and in that bass guitar
that drum beat and Matias Aguayo vocal
on that one I love the effects they lay
on his voice and it just kind of acts
like one more polyrhythm on top of this
groove in the song it is a great job
here they need to work with this guy
again in the future the other guest
vocalists on here pretty good as well
like Gary here in my car Newman he shows
up on the song my machines and Gary does
a great job the guy has not lost it I
think my only complaint is that maybe
his vocals are are pretty high in the
mix if only he could have been sunken
into the instrumentation a little bit
more and maybe if he was given more to
sing just lay more personality into the
track or something like that and I kind
of have a similar gripe with the next
vocal feature on this with Kazuma Chino
from Blonde Redhead she's got a great
voice but I feel like a little bit her
voice is battling with the chirping and
growing keyboards that are just causing
a ruckus underneath her voice
I mean battles does invite these guests
on here but I feel like in a way they
don't really make a lot of room for some
of them and Yaman taka I is on the final
track of this LP and if you know that
guy if you know who that guy is you can
pretty much guess what he does on that
track Wow
but it actually fits in with what
battles is doing really well on that
track he's in the thick of it and making
as much noises everybody else's but I do
want to say even though not every vocal
spot on this LP is
fantastic I love that battles is doing
this they need to continue doing this on
future albums inviting different guests
on the LP seeing what direction their
personality and their voice brings the
album in its very Gorillaz ish and i
like it for that there are a few spots
here where babbles throw some shorties
on this album tracks that are like one
or two minutes long and normally i would
just be like the filler but i'm actually
as impressed with those tracks as i am
some of the other tracks on here
dominican fate is so fun with all these
handclaps and just that that giant bass
drum and the song toddler even though
that's the shortest it has the prettiest
melody on here delivered by the shyest
keyboards around and the song rolls bass
is one of the biggest head bobbers on
here the last thing i guess i can say
about this LP is the recording the
production way up way up just everything
sounds so clear and so loud and so in my
face I mean the drums are so crisp and
loud on this thing it's like I'm
standing in a giant room and listening
to them seeing them being played right
in front of me and the guitars are
always in a nice spot even when they're
being layered over each other whether
it's with a loop pedal or multi-tracking
I'm not sure but always audible and the
keyboards they're just kind of sparkling
shimmering bleeping and blooping over at
all the album start strong finishes
strong fantastic production fantastic
grooves cohesive sound the volume of
this album the instrumental make up for
the most part of this album isn't going
to be for everybody but still I'm
feeling a light too decent 9 on this
album really good stuff really really
good stuff man
despite this lineup debacle battles have
maintained much of the same energy that
made me fall in love with the band in
the first place but what do you think do
you love this do you hate it why and
what do you think I should be reviewing
next
